title: Resistive forces - changing the drag coefficient

content.description: An object is dropped from rest at <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> near Earth's surface and experiences a resistive force of magnitude <math alttext="k v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi><mi>v</mi></math>, where <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> is the speed of the object and <math alttext="k " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant which depends on a variety of factors. The object reaches a speed of <math alttext="0.5 times v sub uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> at <math alttext="lowercase t equals lowercase t sub 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0.5</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="v sub uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> is the objectâ€™s terminal velocity. If another object has the same mass but a greater value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, what changes would occur to the terminal speed, <math alttext="v sub uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>, and the time it takes to get to half the terminal speed, <math alttext="lowercase t sub 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0.5</mn></msub></math>?
content.question: <math alttext="v sub uppercase T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math><math alttext="lowercase t sub 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub></math>ADecreasesDecreasesBDecreasesNo ChangeCIncreasesDecreasesDIncreasesNo Change

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
